statement.p: In Preview Activity, we learned how to use the limit definition of the derivative to find a formula for f'(x) for a collection of power functions. A different way to think about derivative formulas for certain kinds of functions is to use the perspective that the derivative measures the slope of the tangent line to a given function.

li.p: Consider the function f(x) = x, and observe that this function is linear. What is the value of the slope of f(x) = x at any given point on the graph? What should be the formula for f'(x)?
For the linear function g(x)=2x+1, what is the value of the slope of g at any point on the graph? What should be the formula for g'(x)?
If h(x)=7-\frac{2}{3}x, what do you expect will be the formula for h'(x)?
Suppose that p(x) = 3x - 5 and q(x) = 4x + 8. If r(x) = p(x) + q(x), what do you think will be the formula for r'(x)? Why?
Suppose that p(x) = 3x - 5. If s(x) = -4 \cdot p(x), what do you think will be the formula for s'(x)? Why?
